title: 111_hr5324
content: The Act titled "COBRA Health Benefits Extension Act of 2010" extends COBRA continuation coverage. The COBRA Health Benefits Extension Act of 2010 extends the required period of COBRA continuation coverage for individuals covered under the provision. The COBRA Health Benefits Extension Act of 2010 extends the period of COBRA continuation coverage for eligible individuals, with rules for providing prompt notice of coverage availability. The COBRA Health Benefits Extension Act of 2010 allows states to enforce extended continuation coverage under state programs, without affecting the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. Any extended COBRA coverage will end if other terminating events occur before the scheduled termination date. This section supersedes access to State High Risk Pools. The COBRA Health Benefits Extension Act of 2010 allows states to enforce extended continuation coverage under state programs, without affecting the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. This section supersedes any state law limiting access to State High Risk Pools for qualified beneficiaries with extended COBRA coverage. The term "COBRA continuation provision" refers to the provisions of law related to continuation coverage under specific sections of the Public Health Service Act, Internal Revenue Code, and United States Code. It excludes coverage under health flexible spending arrangements. The term "employment-based health plan" refers to a group health plan as defined in the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 excludes certain types of coverage, such as dental, vision, counseling, or referral services, flexible spending arrangements, and on-site medical facility services primarily consisting of first-aid or wellness care. It also includes governmental plans as defined in the Act. The term "State" includes various territories and jurisdictions such as the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and Guam.
